contradictions.title: Thompson (2011) vs Koutsoumpis (2021): Do H-stripes slim vs plain?

source_a.author: Thompson 2011 Exp 3
source_a.finding: H-striped cylinder = IDENTICAL width to plain. Zero effect.

source_b.author: Koutsoumpis 2021 Exp 1
source_b.finding: H-striped dress = THINNER than plain (d=0.61, p<.001)

contradictions.resolution: Cylinders are uniform; human bodies have non-uniform curvature that creates directional effects absent on cylinders. Koutsoumpis more ecologically valid. H-vs-plain effect exists on bodies but weaker than H-vs-V (x0.3 multiplier).
contradictions.kridha_implication: Apply 0.3x multiplier when comparing striped vs plain (not striped vs opposite-stripe)

contradictions.title: Thompson (2011) vs Taya & Miura (2007): Do vertical stripes slim 3D forms?

source_a.author: Taya & Miura 2007
source_a.finding: V-stripes increase perceived 3D depth -> make cylinders NARROWER

source_b.author: Thompson 2011
source_b.finding: V-stripes make 3D cylinders and mannequins WIDER (up to 10.7%)

contradictions.resolution: Thompson directly tested and found Oppel-Kundt widening dominates on actual 3D objects. Taya & Miura's depth-shrinkage may only operate when depth is AMBIGUOUS (2D pictures). Li & Zaidi (2000) undermines Taya & Miura's theoretical basis.
contradictions.kridha_implication: Assume Thompson correct (V-stripes widen) but carry hidden variable for depth-from-texture on highly curved regions

contradictions.title: Lab studies vs Swami & Harris (2012): THE fundamental disagreement

source_a.author: Thompson, Koutsoumpis, Ashida (lab)
source_a.finding: H-stripes make bodies look THINNER (d=0.37 to d=1.83)

contradictions.resolution: NOT a methodological disagreement — measures two different things. Lab = PERCEPTUAL effects (optical illusions). Swami = JUDGMENT effects (perception + memory + cultural belief). Both correct in their context.
contradictions.kridha_implication: Two scoring modes needed: e-commerce (perceptual coefficients primary, COGNITIVE_OVERRIDE_WEIGHT=0.30) and real-world prediction (cultural belief dominant, COGNITIVE_OVERRIDE_WEIGHT=0.60)

contradictions.title: Koutsoumpis (2021) vs Hu et al. (2020): Dark clothing in real world

source_a.author: Koutsoumpis 2021
source_a.finding: Dark clothing slims d=0.35-0.58; on dark bg d=1.27

source_b.author: Hu et al. 2020
source_b.finding: Dark clothing reduces perceived weight 'slightly'; H-stripes NO effect

contradictions.resolution: Koutsoumpis = controlled max-sensitivity conditions. Hu = real-world noise. Small perceptual effects (0.3-1.3%) barely detectable in noisy real-world data. Lab values are UPPER BOUNDS.
contradictions.kridha_implication: Apply real_world_attenuation multiplier of 0.3-0.6 to all lab-derived coefficients

contradictions.title: Sidhu (2021) vs pure luminance model: Color anomalies

source_a.author: Koutsoumpis luminance model
source_a.finding: Width is monotonic function of luminance (darker=slimmer)

source_b.author: Sidhu 2021
source_b.finding: Grey (L*~50) WIDER than white (L*~90+). Red (L*~35) slim as black (L*~10).

contradictions.resolution: UNRESOLVED. Luminance is necessary but NOT sufficient. Saturation/chroma and 'red effect' (Elliot & Niesta 2008) independently modulate perceived size.
contradictions.kridha_implication: Hue-correction terms needed. Currently estimated with very low confidence (2/5). Tractable A/B testing target.

contradictions.title: Ashida (2013) vs Imai (1982): Size of body-size reversal

source_a.author: Ashida 2013
source_a.finding: Fat figure: Helmholtz weakened to near-zero (PSE~0, NS)

source_b.author: Imai 1982
source_b.finding: Overweight figure: V-stripes 15.37% thinner than H-stripes (full reversal)

contradictions.resolution: Body width difference (Imai wider W:H>0.70 vs Ashida ~0.60-0.65) + task demand (Imai rating scales inflate effect) + gender (Imai male, Ashida female). Crossover W:H~0.52 is interpolated from these two conflicting data points — could be 0.45 to 0.65.
contradictions.kridha_implication: CRITICAL uncertainty. The most dangerous parameter in the model. Validating crossover with Kridha data is single highest-priority research task.

contradictions.title: Thompson Exp 1 height vs width asymmetry

source_a.finding: H-stripes must be 4.5% wider than V-stripes to look equal WIDTH

source_b.finding: V-stripes must be 7.1% taller than H-stripes to look equal HEIGHT

contradictions.resolution: Not a contradiction — genuine asymmetry revealing mechanism. Vertical-Horizontal Illusion (Kunnapas 1955) adds to Helmholtz for height but not width. H-stripes create BOTH Helmholtz elongation AND VHI height enhancement.
contradictions.kridha_implication: Use 4.5% for width predictions (conservative) and 7.1% for height. Separate height_effect and width_effect outputs.

contradictions.title: Avoid horizontal stripes — the biggest wrong call in fashion
contradictions.practitioner_says: Horizontal stripes make you look wider (universal advice since 1813 Japan, 1970s+ Western)
contradictions.resolution: Popular wisdom correct for ~30% of bodies (wider W:H), wrong for ~70% (thinner W:H). Additionally, Swami real-world finding suggests cultural belief may override perceptual slimming in social contexts.

contradictions.title: Wear dark colors to look slimmer — right principle, wrong magnitude
contradictions.practitioner_says: Black is slimming (treated as major effect)
contradictions.academic_says: Black slims 0.19% on white backgrounds (NS). Up to 1.33% on dark backgrounds. Popular advice overstates by 10-50x.
contradictions.resolution: Technically correct but effect is TINY in e-commerce contexts. Meaningful only in dark environments. Practitioners intuit OTHER benefits (hides texture, reduces strain lines, psychological confidence) that are real but unmeasured.
contradictions.who_is_right: Both — practitioners right about direction, wrong about magnitude via pure optics. Practitioners capture unmeasured functional benefits.

contradictions.title: Vertical lines elongate — right mechanism, wrong application
contradictions.academic_says: V-stripes make bodies WIDER (Thompson Exp 3). 8-12+ vertical elements trigger Oppel-Kundt widening.
contradictions.resolution: 1-3 vertical LINES (princess seams) produce HVI elongation (-2-4%). But 30+ vertical STRIPES (pinstripes) produce Oppel-Kundt widening (+3-7%). Advice conflates 'lines' with 'stripes'.
contradictions.who_is_right: Practitioners right for FEW lines, wrong for MANY stripes

contradictions.title: Match pattern scale to body scale — zero evidence
contradictions.practitioner_says: Petite=small prints, plus-size=large prints (stated as settled fact)
contradictions.academic_says: No peer-reviewed study has tested this. Zero quantified evidence.
contradictions.resolution: UNRESOLVED. Could be correct, incorrect, or body-type-dependent.

contradictions.title: Warm colors make you look bigger — backwards for red
contradictions.practitioner_says: Avoid warm colors (red, orange, yellow) to look slimmer
contradictions.academic_says: Advancing/receding affects DEPTH not WIDTH (PMC11652407 2024). Width: 0.00. Red actually makes bodies look SLIMMER than luminance predicts (Sidhu 2021).
contradictions.resolution: Popular advice backwards for red. Warm/cool is a depth effect, not a size effect.
contradictions.who_is_right: Academic — practitioners fundamentally wrong about mechanism

contradictions.title: Plus-size pinstripe recommendation failure
contradictions.practitioner_says: Plus-size pinstripe blouses are slimming (widely recommended)
contradictions.academic_says: Stripe slimming (-1.42%) nearly perfectly cancelled by Oppel-Kundt widening (+1.40%) when vertical line count exceeds 8-12. Net: -0.20% (essentially zero).
contradictions.resolution: Popular recommendation produces near-zero net effect due to opposing mechanisms.
